publicationStmt.p: Scholarly digital edition of the manuscript by Paolo Monella.

sourceDesc.p: The digital images of the manuscript.

revisionDesc.change: file:///usr/share/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/AI.html#AILC: The c (character) element should be used to mark up any non-lexical character, whether this appears within a word, or outside it. In the following example, the encoder wishes to indicate that the letters are not to be regarded as words (questo potrebbe sostituire il mio w type="alphabemes"?)
Alcuni attributi (ad es. force, function, e altri) hanno valori di datatype data.enumerated. Questo significa che dovrei limitare formalmente i possibili valori con un elemento valList?
Nella documentazione in [sgn4] metti parole vuote con 0 o no?
Si potrebbero trascrivere anche le glossae a margine
È rispettata o no la regola sulle due forme di 'ti': una con legatura per IPA /tsj/?
Find sources for ab006 based on the comments on Donatus (find ab006 and 'note' there)
Togli la punteggiatura 'solo contemporanea' (senza corrispondenza nel MS)?
Cose da fare alla fine dell'intera trascrizione:
vd. se ci sono 'v', o 'ae', o grafemi non dichiarati in GToS, in grafematica
vd. se i brevigrafi (þ, ŋ etc.) hanno per_lo_più o sempre il signif. che suggerisco nella GToS
check for duplicate and unordered word xml:ids, (find "_duplicate" and "_unordered")
Ricordarsi periodicamente di togliere gli spazi seguiti da 'lb'. In VIM l'andata a capo è \n

In 5r.a.10, le lezioni greche 'edein' seguito da 'eidein', e anche 'plion' seguito da 'pleion' sono da discutere in una complicata discussione critico-testuale, anche in considerazione dei testimoni del testo di Prisciano (vd. app. crit. di Keil K.2.71.11). Tra l'altro, dovrei riportare il testo dei testimoni del testo di Prisciano nella nota contenutistica a quel punto.

I always put a space at the end of the lb, cb, pb elements (XHTML-style). I'm afraid that this is not the TEI-style, and that TEI has no space at the end of such elements: if so, delete it from this file, from vimrc and from the paoloMarkDown.py script.

Filologia testuale: 'quoniam' (xml:id w18300) mi pare strano: controllalo. La fonte (Prisc. Ars K.2.78.20) ha 'quia' che introduce un'oggettiva. Ma può 'quoniam' introdurre oggettive? O lo scriba ha frainteso 'quia' pensandolo introduttore di causale?

ref.note: CiaoThis title (marked as 'head') is in uncial. Another GToS for the uncial script would be necessary.

unclear.w: legeIt seems that something similar to 'ut lege' was written in the same line, then was erased and a new 'ut lege' was written in its place. Also, there is a faded sign over the initial 'u'. This sign looks like a French circumflex accent and already occurred earlier in the same line (above the previous 'ut').
ut There is a faded sign over the initial 'u'. This sign looks like a '^' accent and already occurred earlier in the same line (above the previous 'ut').
est The ink is faded here, however it is possible to see a sign above the 'e'. It might mark the fact that the sentence is interrogative.

ab.n: De oratione: introduction to the parts of speech

ref.note: For section ab0006 Morelli 1910, 291 mentions the following sources: "Donato K. IV. 372 25 sgg. e commentatori di Donato; Prisc. 54 segg." Donatus and Priscianus are imitated quite loosely in this section. I should inquire better about the commentaries on Donatus though. More specific imitations on Priscianus included in this section are referenced directly. Possible comments on Donatus might include: (A) Seruius, K.4.405-K.4.448. For example K.5.81-K.5.312 and in particular on the parts of speech K.5.134 ff." For section ab0006 Morelli 1910, 291 mentions the following sources: "Donato K. IV. 372 25 sgg. e commentatori di Donato; Prisc. 54 segg." Donatus and Priscianus are imitated quite loosely in this section. I should inquire better about the commentaries on Donatus though. More specific imitations on Priscianus included in this section are referenced directly. Possible comments on Donatus might include: (A) Seruius, K.4.405-K.4.448. For example see K.4.428.8 ff. for the parts of speech and lines 11-13 in particular (on page 428 a new author starts: Seruius/Sergius); (B) Pompeius K.5.81-K.5.312 and in particular on the parts of speech K.5.134 ff.
There seems to be a peculiar punctuation sign here, that I am not encoding because I'm not sure about it.
From this column, the handwriting, the script and also the punctuation conventions seem to be different.

Here Ursus follows Priscianus 2.54.8 closely. The source has: "partes igitur orationis sunt secundum dialecticos duae, nomen et |uerbum, quia hae solae etiam per se coniunctae plenam faciunt orationem"

unclear.note: In fact, if we include the 'interiectio', the parts of the speech become six, not five as announced.

From this point on, I'm marking the text with the help of an external Python script. First, I mark the text by using my own simplified 'markdown' conventions, then I run the script that converts that 'markdown' to XML/TEI markup.

nomaOn the linguistic layer (LL), this word won't be able to be processed by a parser, as it does not exist in common dictionaries. Priscianus means this to be a previous (no longer existing) form of the word ὄνομα.

add.note: This is an explanatory interlinear glossa. In the mansucript, it is linked to the main text by means of a cross sign between 'nascitur' and 'ut'. The text in the glossa is closer to the text of Priscianus (the source of this passage).

Morelli 1910, p. 292 writes that the passage connecting the terms for the four types of proper names to future infinitives has no ancient source.
ref.w: infiniti The scribe made a grammar mistake by writing 'infiniti' for 'infinitis'.

w.note: This grapheme looks like a 'p' with both a bottom-left tail (which would make it a 'ŋ' sign, abbreviation for 'pro') and a horizontal dash crossing the descending trait (which would make it a 'þ' sign, abbreviation for 'per'). Probably the same hand first wrote the abbreviation for 'per', than changed his mind and added the bottom-left tail that made it an abbreviation for 'pro'.

ref.w: abitu Spelling mistake: omission of the initial 'h', unvoiced at the time of the scribe.

ab.n: De nomine: definition of appellatiua nomina

ref.note: The rest of the line is blank, and is filled with a note from another hand, in a different script and black (not brown) ink. In the rest of the column, the same black ink was used to restore faded graphemes.

ab.n: De nomine: types of appellatiua nomina

ref.w: sunt This piece of the page was either damaged or (more probably) erased, then the word was written by another hand in black ink. Graphemes 'nt' are written above the line.
ref.note: The word 'sunt' and the first three graphemes of 'incorporales' ('inc') are written in black ink, possibly over a correction.
ref.w: synonima The initial 's' is written with black ink.

gentile The initial 'g' is written in black ink. It is apparent here that the first hand (writing in brown ink) had written this 'g' with its regular shape and size, and the second hand (writing in black ink) derased the original 'g' and wrote it over the rasura with a larger grapheme in capital form. All word initial graphemes in lines 31-35 are in black ink. Some of them are clearly written over a rasura.

The larger initial grapheme is written in black ink over a rasura (same situation as 'gentile' above).
relatiua The larger initial grapheme is written in black ink over a rasura (same situation as 'gentile' above).
patronomica The source Priscianus Keil 2.60.2 has 'patronymicum'.
ref.note: In this case the diphthong 'ae' seems to be written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ'.
ref.w: gradidus Both 'd's in the manuscript seem to be due to a correction (by overwriting). The second 'd' was originally a 'b': on the one hand, the '-ibus' ending is very common in Latin; on the other hand, 'b' for 'u' was a common spelling error due to the contemprorary pronunciation of Latin. I cannot read what was originally written over the current first 'd'.

Strangely enough, 'em' here is abbreviated with 'æ' and the '2' abbreviation sign. Also, while we tend to write 'quemadmodum' as one word, and as such I am encoding it at the Lingustic Layer, the scribe spells it as two words, with a graphical space in between: 'quem' 'admodum'. In consideration of the fact that the scribe often writes 'ad' with no space after it, it might also be that the scribe is writing this expression as three separate words: 'quem', 'ad' and 'modum'.

qų qu
od The source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, 2.60.19) has: 'Ad aliquid dictum est, quod sine intellectu illius, ad quod dictum est, proferri non potest'. Also, in the only previous instance of the 'ų' abbreviation mark (a 'u'-like sign over the 'q'), in 1v.a.3, the word is 'quod'. However, in 1v.a.3 the last two graphemes were clearly 'o' and 'd', while here the sign(s) after the 'q' and 'u'-like abbreviation mark are less clear to me.

ref.note: Over the words 'quis', 'qualis', 'quantus' and 'quot' the scribe wrote a horizontal dash meaning their interrogative role in a sentence. Over 'quotus' this sign has the shape of a French circumflex accent.

mouilisThe scribe wrote 'mouili': an error facilitated by the contemporary pronunciation.

neriThe scribe mistakenly wrote 'generi' instead of 'generis'.
nonumFor 'tertiusdecimus' and 'nonumdecimum', I think that the scribe meant to write the two components of each word ('tertius' and 'decimus', as well as 'nonum' and 'decimum') separately.
uicesimusThere is a macron over the 'e' of 'uicesimus', but I don't understand what function it could have here.

nongentesi
m; mus
This is a fairly rare case in which the final ';' abbreviation mark is used to mean a final '-us' morpheme. Also, the last 'n' in 'nongeNtesimus' is written above the line.

epimerizomenaThe source of this passage is Priscian 'De figuris numerorum' (Keil 3.413.24) and has ἐπιμεριζόμενα. The handwriting in the manuscript is almost completely faded, especially the letters after 'epi-' and before '-omena'. However, based on the number of graphemes that seem to be in this word the scribe probably wrote a shorter word than ἐπιμεριζόμενα, possibly something like 'epirizomena'.

¢ qui
nquiesThe 'n' is written above the line.

sexcen
tiesThe 'n' is written above the line
ref.note: The source of this passage, Priscian 'De figuris numerorum' (Keil 3.415.24-26), after 'milies', has: 'Infinitis tamen numerorum aduerbiis etiam n interponitur, quotiens totiens, similiter multotiens. Inueniuntur et aliae deriuationes uel compositiones multae a nominibus numerorum, ut unicus...'. Probably the scribe initially skipped the sentence 'Infinitis... multotiens' (line 24 in Keil) and started copying from the sentence 'Inueniuntur et aliae deriuationes' (line 26 in Keil), so he wrote 'inueniuntur' (which originally had the initial 'i' written with a larger size). Then, he decided not to skip the sentence 'Infinitis tamen numerorum...' and copied it after 'inueniuntur', but he forgot to erase 'inueniuntur', which remained in the manuscript as a relic. The same scribe at a later time (or someone else) then erased the large initial 'i' of 'inueniuntur', overwrote it in rasura with a smaller size, and also overwrote the initial 'i' of 'infinitis' with a larger font. As usual, I kept the the original punctuation in the Graphemic Layer and put my contemporary punctuation in the Linguistic Layer. The reason why no scribe decided to erase 'inueniuntur' is probably that it could seem to belong to the previous sentence, which I don't believe. In an interpretive edition, the word 'inueniuntur' shoud therefore be omitted.
ref.w: septimaniaThe handwriting is not clear, but after the 'n' there seem to be more than just an 'a'.

ref.note: The quote 'iure... ferret' corresponds to Persius, Saturae, 3.48 (urn:cts:latinLit:phi0969:phi001:3.48).

ref.note: Verg. Aen. 10.213 (urn:cts:latinLit:phi0690.phi003:10.213).

Keil, volume 3, page 416, in the apparatus criticus writes 'Lucan. Pharsal. VIII 444'. The edition of A. E. Housman, 1927 has the following text for Lucanus, Bellum ciuile 8.444-447: Syrtibus hinc Libycis tuta est Aegyptos, at inde / gurgite septeno rapidus mare summouet amnis. / terra suis contenta bonis, non indiga mercis / aut Iouis: in solo tanta est fiducia Nilo (urn:cts:latinLit:phi0917.phi001:8.444-8.447).
ref.w: queIn this case the diphthong 'ae' seems to be written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ'.

undeuigintiThe original hand (in brown ink) must have written something wrong. A second hand (in black ink) corrected to unum (written as 'unu' with a '2-like' abbreviation mark over the final 'u', plus one or two illegible signs. The source (Priscian Keil 3.416.6) has 'undeuiginti'.
ref.note: Hor. Sermones 2.3.117-118 (urn:cts:latinLit:phi0893.phi004:2.3.117-2.3.118)
ref.w: lxxuiiiiThe glyph for the 'five' sign here is pointy like modern 'v', not rounded like that normally used for 'u' in the manuscript.
inueniturOver the second 'i' there is a ^ sign, whose meaning I don't understand.
uniformisThe larger font was added to the initial 'u' by a second hand.
quadragessisThe 's' after the 'e' was added above the line.
quæmThe scribe mistakenly wrote 'quæm' with the 'æ' grapheme.

uAs above, the glyph for the numeral 'five' is pointy like modern 'v', not rounded.

t
a2 am
qu
a2 am
The 'u' is written above the line, with the pointy shape of modern 'v'.
atauis There is a macron sign over the initial 'a'. If it were an abbreviation mark for 'an'. This would create a mispelling 'antauis' for 'atauis'.

letoides The source (Priscian, Institutiones, Keil 2.63.12-2.63-13) has 'Latoides, Λητοῦς, id est Latonae'. Maybe the scribe wrote 'Letoides' (with 'e') instead of 'Latoides' based on the Greek spelling with 'eta'.
meiades The source (Priscian, Institutiones, Keil p. 64 line 3) has 'Maiades'. The manuscript has a macron sign over the first 'e', that I cannot interpret and therefore did not encode.

i I think that this grapheme here means the letter 'i' as part of the varian form 'Aenidae', rather than as number 'I' as in 'in book I'. The variant form 'Aenidae' is found later in the source: it is not found in Priscian, Institutiones, 2.64.10-2.65.6 but in 2.66.2-2.66.3.
eneas There is a macron over 'ea', which I can't interpret.
anchisæ There is a macron over 'is', which I can't interpret.
atauis There is a macron sign over the initial 'a'. If it were an abbreviation mark for 'an'. This would create a mispelling 'antauis' for 'atauis'.

qu
a2 am
Scribe's mistake: 'quam' for 'qua'.

dyphthong
u2 um
Scribe's mistake: 'y' for 'i' in the first syllable.
ref.note: The source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, Keil 2.65.18-2.65.20) has: 'Si nominatiuus Graecus in 'ας' uel in 'ης' uel 'ιος' desinat, genetiuus uero in 'ου' diphthongum, a paenultima breuis ante 'des' inuenitur in patronymico', but different branches of the textual tradition of Priscian have different Greek letters. Codex R ('cod. bibl. imp. Paris. 7496'), first and second hand: 'in as (with ac written above the word) uel in es (with EC written above the word) uel os (with IOC written above the word)'. Codex B ('cod. bibl. publ. Bambergensis'): 'ac uel HC uel IOC'. Codex b (same codex, second hand): 'in ac uel ī HC uel ī IOC'. Codex D ('cod. bibl. publ. Bernensis, olim Bongarsianus'): 'in as uel in es uel in ios'. Codex G ('cod. bibl. conventus Sangallensis'), first and second hand: 'in as (with 'uel es' written above the line) uel ios'. Codex K ('cod. bibl. Caroliruhensis 223'): 'in ac uel IOC uel HC'. Codex H ('cod. bibl. gymn. Halberstadiensis, Lutherius Krehlii'): 'ac uel HC uel IOC'. Codex L ('cod. bibl. publ. Lugd. Bat. olim Gruterianus'): 'in as uel in os'. The reading 'os' appears only in codex R, but the error of the scribe of this manuscript might have arisen independently.
ref.w: peliades There is a macron over the 'i', probably marking the short quantity of the letter. I am not encoding these quantity marks in the graphematic transcription because they do not have graphematic value, i.e. they do not create "minimal pairs" of words.
æneas There is a ^ sign over the 'e' (the 'e' between the 'n' and the 'a'), probably marking the long quantity of the letter.
æneades There is a ^ sign over the 'e' (the 'e' between the 'n' and the 'a'), probably marking the long quantity of the letter.
ænides There is a ^ sign over the 'i' (the 'i' between the 'n' and the 'd'), probably marking the long quantity of the letter.
ænides There is a ^ sign over the 'i' (the 'i' between the 'n' and the 'd'), probably marking the long quantity of the letter.
ref.note: The scribe wrote: 'a Graecis 'es' terminatibus', but he probably meant 'a Graecis in 'es' terminantibus'.
ref.w: priamos There is an acute accent sign over the 'i', marking the quantity of the vowel. I'm not recording such signs because they do not have graphemic value, i.e. they do not create 'minimal pairs' of words.
peleis There is an acute accent mark over the 'i'.
peleosThere is an acute accent mark over the second 'e'.
peleidesThere is an acute accent mark over the second 'e'.
pelidesThere is an acute accent mark over the 'i'.
peleidesThere is an acute accent mark over the second 'e'.
ænidesThere is a ^ mark over the 'n'.

ref.w: oelides There is a macron sign over the 'i' to mark its long quantity. I'm not marking it because it has no graphematic value. Keil chooses the reading 'Aeclides' (Priscian, Institutiones K 2.67.9, the direct source of this passage), but in the apparatus criticus he mentions the reading 'Oelides', very common in Priscian's textual tradition. This is the apparatus note for K 2.67.0: 'Aeclides] ex aeolides corr. in litura B f. recte: patron. sc. ab Aeclo, Eretriae conditore, quamvis exemplum desidero; aeolides D Hrabanus p. 33 oelides RHGLK'.

ref.note: The source (Priscian, Institutiones K 2.68.10) has the whole verse 'Acrisioneis Danae fundasse colonis' (Verg. Aen. 7.410.
ref.w: acrisionea Keil (Priscian, Institutiones K 2.68.11, the direct source of this passage) chooses the reading 'ab Acrisione', but in the apparatus criticus he mentions the reading 'acrisionea' from codices H ('cod. bibl. gymn. Halberstadiensis, Lutherius Krehlii'), and r ('cod. bibl. imp. Paris. 7496', second hand).

danaa Keil (Priscian, Institutiones K 2.68.11, the direct source of this passage) chooses the reading 'Danae', but in the apparatus criticus he mentions the reading 'danaa' from codices R ('cod. bibl. imp. Paris. 7496') and K ('cod. bibl. Caroliruhensis 223'), while codices D ('cod. bibl. publ. Bernensis, olim Bongarsianus') and H ('cod. bibl. gymn. Halberstadiensis, Lutherius Krehlii') have a similar reading.

troias Keil (Priscian, Institutiones K 2.68.13, the direct source of this passage) chooses the reading 'Troas', but in the apparatus criticus he mentions the reading 'troias' from codices D ('cod. bibl. publ. Bernensis, olim Bongarsianus'), H ('cod. bibl. gymn. Halberstadiensis, Lutherius Krehlii') and K ('cod. bibl. Caroliruhensis 223').
ref.note: The rest of the line is left blank. In this space, a second hand has written in black ink a note that should read: 'De possessiuis nominibus' (with abbreviations for 'de', 'mini' and 'bus').

ref.w: nepotes The 's' is written above the line.
hae In this case the diphthong is spelled with two graphemes 'ae'.

a The manuscript has the grapheme 'u' for the alphabeme 'u', which proves to me that the scribe had the Greek letter in mind here, therefore I am encoding it in Greek (not in Latin) at the Linguistic Layer for the three letters mentioned in this sentence (α, ι and υ).
cypriacus There is a macron sign over the 'i', meaning that the sound is short.
italicus There is a macron sign over the 'i', meaning that the sound is short.

This is the first time that I find this abbreviation. It might also be interpreted as a brevigraph, composed of a 'b' grapheme with a long horizontal trait crossing the vertical line.
ref.note: Keil in his edition of Priscian, Institutiones K 2.69.23, the direct source of this passage, expunges the sentence 'quod a principali accepit', though it seems to exist in all manuscripts.
The page has a six-lines high circular hole. It already existed when the scribe wrote, because the text is written around it.
ref.w: deribantur Scribe error: 'b' for 'u', due to the pronunciation of the time.

ha
b¯ bent
The source of this passage (Priscian, Institutiones K 2.69.27, has 'et si promitiua illa habuerint i paenultimam', but I think that the expansion of this abbreviation should simply be 'habent'.
italus There is a macron over the 't' both in 'Italus' and 'Italicus', but I do not understand their meaning.
cypriacus There is a line in the shape of an acute accent over the 'i', that could mean the word stress.
cypricus There is a line in the shape of an acute accent over the 'y', that could mean the word stress.
mulionicus An acute accent-shaped sign over the 'o' marks the word stress.
cesareus There is a macron over the 'a', marking its long quantity.
spondeus A macron over the 'e' marks its long quantity.
phoebeus A macron over the 'e' marks its long quantity.
ariusius A macron over the first 'u' marks its long quantity.

w.note: The glyph for 'o' has a dot in the middle.
The abbreviation sign crossing the ascending trait of the 'd' looks like a tilde rather than like a macron.

ref.w: erous A macron over the 'o' marks its long quantity.
eous A macron over the 'o' marks its long quantity.
ae The 'a' is not particulalry large, but it is written with the glyph usually used when it is larger then the rest of the text.
sabaeus In this case the diphthong 'ae' is written with two graphemes 'a' and 'e'.
feminis The source of this passage (Priscian, Institutiones K 2.70.46, has 'femininis', which is an obvious correction here.
cretaeus In this case the diphthong 'ae' is written with two graphemes 'a' and 'e'.
hylaeus In this case the diphthong 'ae' is written with two graphemes 'a' and 'e'.
dionaeus In this case the diphthong 'ae' is written with two graphemes 'a' and 'e'.
timaeus In this case the diphthong 'ae' is written with two graphemes 'a' and 'e'.
oe The glyph for 'o' has a dot in the middle.
euboea In this case the diphthong 'ae' is written with two graphemes 'a' and 'e'.
quæm The manuscript seems to have a 'æ' grapheme. This is probably a scribal error for 'quam' (referred to the feminine diphthongus mentioned before, in line 6.

Scribal error: initial 'c' for 'g'.
ref.note: The Greek words I encoded at the Linguistic Layer (ᾔδην and ᾔδειν) are Keil's corrections. The original text of the Casanatensis is that encoded at the Graphematic Layer. The manuscripts of Priscianus (the source here is Priscianus K.2.71.11), as reported in Keil's apparatus criticus, often have the same (transliterated) readings as the Casanatensis. This is a fairly serious textual critical problem. Keil's apparatus note to ᾔδην has: "11 ᾔδην scripsi, cf. Eustath. ad Hom. Od. XIII 220 Sturzium de dial. Gr. p. 64 C.". As to the readings found in the manuscripts, the apparatus has: "ΗΔΗΝ H ΗΔ.ΙΝ Rr ΗΔΕ*Ν*(Ι) D ΗΔΕΝ K eden GL". For ᾔδειν, Keil's apparatus has: "ᾔδειν scripsi ΕΙΔΕΙΝ R eid*n (i) D eiden HGLK" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum)

The Greek words I encoded at the Linguistic Layer (πλῆον and πλεῖον) are Keil's corrections. The original text of the Casanatensis is that encoded at the Graphematic Layer. The manuscripts of Priscianus (the source here is Priscianus K.2.71.11), as reported in Keil's apparatus criticus, never have 'plion', but do have 'pleion'. This is another fairly serious textual critical problem. This is Keil's apparatus note for πλῆον: "ΠΑΗΩΝ Rr ΠΑΗΟΝ D ΠΕΛΗΟΝ d ΠΗΛΗΩΝ GL ΠΛΗΟΝ H ΠΛΕΟΝ K". This is his note for πλεῖον: "ΠΛΕΙΟΝ ex ΠΛΕΙΙΟΝ corr. in lit. r peλeion ex ΠΕΑΑΕΙΟΝ ni f. corr. d ΠΗΛΕΙΩΝ L peleion K peion H".
The last part of the line is blank (for the space of about a word).

The manuscript has a punctuation sign between 'i' and 'us', and I am encoding the text as such also at the Linguistic Layer (i.e. I am encoding two different endings, 'i' and 'us'), but the source (Priscianus K.2.71.13) has 'ius' and this is probably the reading that best fits the sense of the text. I consider this a scribal error.

ref.w: audii This word has a 'u'-shaped sign over the first 'i' to mark its short quantity.

isti There is a 'u'-shaped sign over the first 'i' to mark its short quantity.

audi

There is a 'u'-shaped sign over the 'i' to mark its short quantity.
audieras There is a 'u'-shaped sign over the 'i' to mark its short quantity.
audiui There is a macron sign over the first 'i' to mark its long quantity.

ei The source (Priscian Ars Grammatica K.2.74.17) has 'ai' here, which would be more consistent with the following example of Greek Ἀχαιός. Keil's apparatus says that 'ai' is the reading of r, d and h, while 'ae' is the reading of R, D and H (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum), which means that in all those three manuscripts a second hand has corrected 'ae' to 'ai'.

interposit
u2 um
This is certainly a scribe error for 'interposito'. Compare the source Priscian Ars Grammatica K.2.74.18: 'interposita similiter u pro consonante'. As the 'u' in the manuscript has been added at a later time above the line, the original text was 'in i longum interpositum', where 'interpositum' modified 'i'. The correction restored the missing 'u' but forgot to change 'interpositum' to 'interposito' to make 'u interposito' an absolute ablative.
cui Probably a scribal error for 'cum', which is the reading in the source (Priscian Ars Grammatica K.2.74.18).

ae The manuscript has the Latin diphthong 'ae'. Among the manuscripts of Priscianus, according to Keil's apparatus, H and g (which is the second hand of G) have the Latin diphthong 'ae', while h (the second hand of H) has corrected it to the Greek diphthong 'ai'.

ŋ pro
fec
torius The source, Priscian Ars Grammatica K.2.75.5, has 'praefectorius'. In the manuscript the word starts with a brevigraph that elsewhere always has the alphabetical meaning of 'pro', so we can consider this a scribal error ('profectorius' for 'praefectorius').
agria The source (Priscian Ars Grammatica K.2.75.11) has 'agraria'.
romanus There is a macron sign over the 'a' to mark its long quantity.

abienus On the possible meanings of this word, see Keil's apparatus to the source of this passage, Priscian Ars grammatica, K.2.75.19. Priscian's manuscripts tend to agree on 'abienus'. Codex H ('cod. bibl. gymn. Halberstadiensis, Lutherius Krehlii') has a glossa saying 'nomen poetae'.
ref.note: 'Terrenus', 'egenus', 'abienus' and 'Anienus' all have a macron sign over the penultimate 'e' to mark its long quantity.

ref.w: liuertinus Scribal error due to the contemporary pronunciation: 'liuertinus' for 'libertinus'.
syllanus There is a macron sign over the 'a' to mark its long quantity.
romanus There is a macron sign over the 'a' to mark its long quantity.
messala The name from which 'Messalinus' derives should rather be 'Messalla'. The source (Priscian, Ars grammatica K.2.77.14 does not mention the primitive names for 'Iugurthinus' or 'Messalinus'.
serbant Scribal error due to the contemporary pronunciation: 'serbant' for 'seruant'.
ref.note: This line only has one word, at the right end.

Keil publishes the following text for the source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, K.2.77.17: "a habent ante 'nus' [uel 'na' uel 'num']". However, the text that Keil expunges is present in all manuscripts and was also the text that Ursus knew.
ref.w: membrana The source Priscian Ars grammatica K.2.77.19 has 'membra membrana'.
ref.note: Though the manuscript has a middle dot between 'i' and 'e', the whole morpheme 'ie' is meant.
In both 'cotidie' and 'cotidianus', the first hand had a double 't' ('cottidie' and 'cottidianus'), but the first 't' was deleted.
ref.w: masculinus There is a macron sign over the 'i' to mark its long quantity.

ŋ pro
duc
t
u2 um

w.note: This word is a very interesting use case for the encoding of abbreviations. The macron that crosses the long ascending trait of the 'd' might well be interpreted as being not only over the 'd', but also over the first grapheme. The latter, however, already is an abbreviation, since it is a 'ŋ' brevigraph normally meaning 'prae' ('pre' with monophthongation). So the first grapheme would be involved in two different abbreviations: it is a brevigraph per se, but it is also part of the abbreviation involving the whole word (marked by the macron above it). However, in my JavaScript code handling the XML/TEI code, I did not think of handling a case in which an 'abbr' element is child of another 'abbr' element. Also, the macron is mostly over the 'd', so I am encoding this as though the macron was over the 'd' only.

ref.w: marinus There is a macron sign over the 'i' to mark its long quantity.
herculinus There is a macron sign over the 'i' to mark its long quantity.
ref.note: Though there is a middle dot between 'i' and 'um', the morpheme that the author meant proably was 'ium' as a whole (compare the source, Priscian Ars grammatica, K.2.79.2: 'et in ium propria').
ref.w: austrinus There is a macron sign over the 'i' to mark its long quantity.
